B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

5. 
While  LSE  in  Viet  Nam  has  made  remarkable  progress  in  recent  years,  the  following 
constraints  need  to  be  addressed:  (i)  quality  and  efficiency,  (ii) access  and  equity,  and  (iii) 
management capacity. The sector and subsector analysis is in Appendix 2. 
 
6. 
The quality of LSE needs to be improved in terms of student learning achievements.  A 
system of periodic, sample-based learning assessments is required to evaluate the curriculum 
and  teacher  effectiveness  and  hence,  quality  improvements  in  education.  However,  such 
assessments focus largely on lower order cognitive skills (knowledge of facts) and students tend 
to  focus  their  learning  on  developing  retentive  memories.  Learning  assessments  need  to  be 
aligned with the goals of the new curriculum. There are about 260,000 LSE teachers in school 
year 2002/03, of whom an estimated 237,000 (or 91% of the total LSE teachers) were qualified. 
However, to help improve quality, most in-service teachers, even those with formal qualifications, 
need  to  update  their  teaching  skills  and  be  familiar  with  curricular  changes  and  new  teaching 
methods.  Active,  student-centered  teaching  and  learning  methods  have  been  piloted  and 
introduced  nationwide.  However,  teaching  styles  are  still  largely  teacher-centered  and  not 
enough  attention  is  paid  to  individual  student  differences  in  interest  and  capacity. A challenge 
will  be  to  fully  make  classroom  teaching  and  learning  active  and  student  centered.  In-class 
instructional  time  is  low  by  international  standards.  Many  schools  operate  on  a  double  shift 
system; some share school buildings with the local primary schools and offer only an average 
teacher contact  of  less  than  4  hours  a  day.  To  meet  international  standards,  teacher  contact 
should  be  6  hours  per  day  for  a  5-day,  40-week  school  year.  The  supply  of  textbooks  and 
instructional materials also varies by household income level, school location, and subject area. 
Schools need more and better teaching aids, equipment and function rooms, especially libraries, 
science laboratories, and computer rooms.  
 
7. 
Internal  efficiency  remains  low,  with  higher  dropout  and  class  repetition  rates  than  the 
national  average  rate  in  some  regions  of  the  country  such  as  the  central  highlands,  Mekong 
River delta, and northwest.  Overage  students  are numerous  as  a  result  of  delayed  entry  and 
repetition.  The  average  time  for  completing  LSE  is  about  5.4  years,  compared  with  4  years  if 
students  do  not  have  to  repeat  grades  or  drop  out.  There  is  little  data  on  external  efficiency 
based  on  the  students’  completion  of  LSE,  and  it  is  a  weakness  that must  be addressed to 
adequately assess LSE responsiveness to human resources demands.   
 
8. 
Limited  access,  especially  by  the  poor  and  ethnic  minorities,  remains  a  problem.  
Disparities  among  provinces  and  among  districts  in  a  province  are  also  significant.  NERs  of 
provinces  in  poor  regions  such  as  the  northern  uplands,  central  coast,  central  highlands,  and 
Mekong  River  delta  were  below  the  national  average  rate  of  about  72%  in  2002.  Achieving 
universal  LSE  requires  a  targeted  approach  by  focusing  on  specific  provinces,  districts, and 
ethnic  minority  groups.  The  main  reason  for  the  differences  in  lower  secondary  enrollment 
across  income  categories  (para.  3)  has  to  do  with  the  opportunity  cost  of  sending  children  to 
school.  Poor  students  need  to  boost  family  income  or  assist  in  the  household.  Parents, 
especially among the poor and ethnic minorities, do not sufficiently value education to send their 
children to lower secondary school or keep them there. Moreover, there are other specific and 
interrelated constraints on access and equity to LSE: (i) the number of lower secondary schools 
is insufficient; (ii) schools are too far away for reasonable daily access by school-age children; 
(iii) boarding school facilities at the nearest available lower secondary school are lacking; and iv) 
students do not finish primary school or finish it too late to reasonably attend lower secondary

Educational and Technical Benefits

the LSE subsector, and achieve the Government’s goal of universalizing quality LSE by 2010. In 
particular, the Project is expected to contribute to important long-term benefits, including (i) the 
adoption  of  student-centered  teaching  contents  and  teaching  methods  that  emphasize  the 
development of higher order thinking and life skills; (ii) periodic assessments of student learning 
outcomes that provide important feedback to teachers, textbook writers, curriculum developers, 
and school administrators at all levels; (iii) increases in the number of classrooms and facilities

at  the  lower  secondary  level;  and  (iv)  improvements  in  decentralized  education  management

2.  

Efficiency Benefits 

 
The  Project  will  directly  improve  the  efficiency  of  LSE  in  a  number  of  concrete, 
56. 
measurable ways. It will increase enrollment rates at the lower secondary level by constructing 
and replacing classrooms, and at the same time providing direct support to attract and retain  in 
LSE  students  from  disadvantaged  and  ethnic  minority  groups.  Low  internal  and  external 
efficiencies  will  be  overcome  through  project  interventions.  Dropout  and  grade  repetition  rates 
will  be  reduced  by  the  improved  instructional  environment  through  better  teacher-student 
interaction,  and  high-quality  textbooks  and  instructional  materials,  which  in  turn  will  increase 
internal efficiency. The Project will increase  the external efficiency of LSE. External efficiency in 
education is  usually  measured  by  the  labor  market  performance  of  school  graduates.  At  the 
lower levels, however, the most sensible measure of external efficiency is success in moving to 
the  next  higher  school  level.  Quality  improvements  envisaged  under  the  Project  will  result  in 
higher  overall  test  scores  and  subsequently  higher  transition  rates  to  upper  secondary 
education.

SECTOR AND SUBSECTOR ANALYSIS  
 

1. 
Following the reunification of Viet Nam in 1975, the different systems of education were 
standardized by 1989 into a 16-year system with a 5-4-3-4 structure consisting of preschool with 
optional attendance; primary education with a nominal duration of 5 years, and an official entry 
age of 6 years; lower secondary education, with a duration of 4 years, followed by either upper 
secondary  education  lasting  for  3  years,  or  vocational  and  technical education with programs 
from  2  to  4  years;  and  higher  education  in  either  university  (4–6  years)  or  college  (mainly 
teacher training institutions with 2–3 year courses).  
 
2. 
Education  is  administered  through  a  devolved  system  of  management  and  funding. 
While the Ministry of Education and Training (MOET) has major responsibility for key areas of 
education,  other  ministries  and  local  levels  of  governments  play  significant  roles  in  the 
administration  of  primary  and  secondary,  certain  vocationally  oriented  secondary,  and  higher 
education institutions. The principal responsibilities of MOET are to (i) set policies and priorities 
within a broad planning framework, (ii) review plans of provincial departments of education and 
training (DOETs) and bureaus of education and training (BOETs), (iii) determine overall financial 
costs, and (iv) monitor and supervise the overall education management process. At the DOET 
level,  principal  responsibilities  are  to  (i)  develop  provincial-level  medium-term  plans,  (ii) 
administer upper secondary schools, and (iii) monitor and supervise the work of BOETs. At the 
BOET  level,  principal  responsibilities  are  to  (i)  develop  medium-term  plans  based  on  data 
collected  at  commune  and  school  levels,  and  (ii)  administer  primary  and  lower  secondary 
education.

This current policy of implicit subsidy to LSE is rooted in the notion that education at this level is 
a public good with high social benefits.

Expansion  of  education  in  Viet  Nam  has  been  very  impressive.  Enrollment  has

B.        Economic Analysis 

 
1.  Economic Rationale  

 
3. 
Public and private investments in all levels of education in Viet Nam have been high, as 
evidenced  by  the  expansion  of  school  places  and  increased  participation.  Between 1993 and 
2002,  enrollment  increased  by  3.9%  at  the  primary  level,  by  140%  in  LSE,  and  by  480%  in 
upper  secondary.  Despite  these  achievements,  internal  efficiency  remains  low,  with  high 
dropout  and  class  repetition  rates  in  some  regions  of  the  country.1  Poor  quality  is  shown  in

planning,  budget  allocation,  and  delivery  of  in-service  training  and  other  teacher  support 
services.  To  turn  Viet  Nam’s  decade-long  history  of  economic  growth  into  genuine  poverty 
reduction, the assets of the country’s poor must be augmented and human capital more equally 
distributed. This objective can be achieved either by investing in new assets, specifically, LSE, 
or by redistributing existing assets. By 2010, the Government aims to achieve universal LSE at 
higher  levels  of  quality.  The  Project  will  support  quality  improvements  through  continuing

4.  Cost-Effectiveness and Efficiency Analysis

by  the  SESMP  determined  that  the  fiscal  (government  spending)  cost  per  LSE  student  in

capital and recurrent expenditures are higher in remote and difficult districts and communes. In

LSE  level  is  less  than  the  actual  unit  cost,  implying  the  existence  of  costs  borne  by  individual 
households. The Project supports the adoption of government policy abolishing fees at the LSE. 
The  Government  has  tried  to  hold  constant  or  reduce  the  practice  of  cost  recovery  at  the 
primary  and  lower  secondary  levels  for  the  poor  and  very  few  poor  and  minority  families.  It  is 
also  helping  the  disadvantaged  students  by  subsidizing  out-of-pocket costs that constrain the 
attainment of universal coverage.

enrollment rate between the rich and the poor. Of the 20% poorest households and 20% richest households, only 33.6% of 
the  poorest  households  can  access  LSE  compared  with  91%  of  the  richest  households.The  Project  will  address  issues 
concerning access to and equity in LSE in selected provinces in northern uplands, coastal center, central highlands, north, 
east, south, and Mekong River Delta, which are suffering from slow economic and education development. 
B.  Poverty Analysis   
What  type  of  poverty  analysis  is  needed?  The  poverty  partnership  agreement  with  the  Asian  Development  Bank  was 
signed on 25 February 2002.The most recent estimate of the population of Viet Nam is 80.78 million. Due to a sharp reduction 
in the birth rate, the proportion of children under 15 kept declining, from 39% in 1989 to 35.5% in 1999. While the percentage 
of females in the population is 50.84%, the nationwide ratio of females in the LSE (in 10–14 age group) is 48.26%.There is a 
significant difference in the average living standard between rural and urban areas. The lowest annual per capita income in 
urban areas in 1999 was D2,400,000 ($160), while in rural areas it was D996,000  ($66); the highest annual per capita income 
in urban areas was D23,529,600 ($1,569), and the figure for rural areas was D6,276,000  ($418). The poor in Viet Nam often 
share common features: they live in rural areas, have relatively low levels of educational attainment, large number of children, 
and lack access to social and physical infrastructure.  Poverty has a great effect on participation in LSE of children of school 
age. Early child labor prevents children, especially girls from going to school. More seriously, early marriage is common in 
some remote ethnic minority areas. Official statistics show that, during 1993–1998, less than 50% of children from low-income 
families continued to pursue LSE. Cultural factors and male preference also affect the education of children, especially girls. 
In  recent  years  the  Government  launched  a  National  Target  Poverty  Reduction  Program,  which  focused  on:  developing 
physical  facilities  for  poor  communes;  providing  assistance  for  special  disadvantaged  ethnic  minorities,  resettlement, 
migration  to  new  economic  zones;  training  in  basic  economic  knowledge  for  the  poor;  credit,  health  care,  and  education 
services for the poor; and development of production and local industries. Under socioeconomic development programs for 
special disadvantaged communes in mountains and remote areas, the Government will provide financial assistance to 2,162 
communes. Specific policies in health and education toward poor and ethnic minority populations were under implementation. 
About 1.3 million students are entitled to tuition fee reduction or exemption, and 1.4 million students can borrow textbooks and 
receive  free  textbooks  with  a  total  budget  of  D80  million  from  local  budget  and  education  sector  funds.  However,  the 
resources reserved for poverty reduction programs are still limited and do not meet the demand.  The Project will enhance 
access and quality of LSE for the poor, ethnic minorities, and female students through the following activities: (i) construction 
of  schools  with  priority  for  poor  and  disadvantaged  areas;  provision  of  equipment  and  teaching  aids,  textbook lending, 
boarding -houses for students who live far from school and for poor students; (ii) design of special summer and school year 
flexible programs to help students to master the curriculum; and (iii) organize vocational orientation and training courses on 
traditional handicrafts of ethnic minorities, creating opportunities for them to integrate into society. The Project will focus its 
investment on 28 provinces facing great difficulties, with the following criteria: (i) a low NER, (ii) a large number of very poor 
people or low human development intervention rating, (iii) high number of ethnic minority students, and (iv) low transition rate 
from primary to LSE.
